The board has 64 squares, 8 rows and 8 columns.
Each player starts with 16 pieces: 1 king, 1 queen, 2 rooks, 2 knights, 2 bishops, 8 pawns.
The king moves one square in any direction.
The queen moves any number of squares in any straight or diagonal direction.
The rook moves any number of squares vertically or horizontally.
The bishop moves any number of squares diagonally.
The knight moves in an L-shape: two squares in one direction and one square perpendicular.
Pawns move one square forward, and two squares on their first move.
Pawns capture diagonally one square.
When a pawn reaches the last rank, it can promote to any piece except the king.
Check: when the king is threatened, it must be moved or blocked.
Checkmate: if the king cannot escape, the player loses the game.
Draw: the game can end in a draw if there are no legal moves or the position repeats three times.
Castling: a special king and rook move to safeguard the king.
Short castling: move the king two squares toward the short rook, then move the rook beside it.
Long castling: move the king two squares toward the long rook, then move the rook beside it.
En passant: a pawn can capture an enemy pawn that moved two squares on its first move.
White always moves first.
Illegal moves must be retracted and corrected.
The king cannot move into a threatened square.
Forced moves are not allowed: every move must be legal.
Moves must be recorded in tournaments.
The knight can jump over any piece.
Doubled pawns are weak if blocked by another pawn.
Double attack: threatening two pieces simultaneously.
Fork: the knight can threaten multiple pieces at once.
Opening files for rooks: move pawns to open lines for rooks.
Active pieces dominate the game.
Weak pieces are those rarely moved or exposed.
Connected pawns support each other.
Isolated pawn: a pawn without support from another pawn.
Piece values: the king is the most valuable piece.
The queen is the most powerful piece after the king.
Sacrifice: giving a lower-value piece to disrupt the opponent's plan.
Exchange: trading pieces of equal value to maintain balance.
Long-term planning: think 3-5 moves ahead to win.
Defensive clustering: placing pieces around the king for protection.
